title: East German text typeface
content:
The following is a photograph of the first page of “Willhelm Tell,” a play by Friedrich Schiller. The book was printed by Verlag (publishing house) Philipp Reclam jun. Leipzig in 1970. The text typeface was called _Liberta Antiqua_.

I am curious if there are digitizations of this typeface. Or, if not, which typeface would be a good approximation of it.

Thanks :-)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414113736im_/http:/typophile.com/files/liberta-antiqua_3425.jpg)

Font: 

 Trybuna 

Solved By: 

 [Michel Boyer](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414113736/http:/typophile.com/user/18942 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [liberta-antiqua.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414113736/http:/typophile.com/files/liberta-antiqua.jpg) | 137.51 KB |
author: _savage

comments.content: According to Luc Devroye, that font has been revived by Ralph Unger as [Trybuna](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414113736/http:/www.identifont.com/find?font=trybuna&q=Go)

Thank you, **Michel**! Looks like I can download the font from e.g. [myfonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414113736/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/rmu/trybuna/), though not directly through [Ralph's website](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414113736/http:/www.dtp-studio-unger.de/fontdesign.html). Indeed, Trybuna looks _very_ close to what's on that text page!

The only difference is in the German character ß which I like better in its "original" printed form :)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414113736im_/http:/typophile.com/files/trybuna-sz_6298.jpg)

According to an email from Ralph: "es ist einfach ein typographisches Update von mir, da sich die Originalform des „sz“ nach der damaligen „Mode“ richtete." (That [the different ß] was a typographic update I made, because the original form of the „sz“ conformed to the „fashion“ of that time.)
